pullRequest.body:
This PR defines the closure of a set in a matroid, and provides some API. 

---

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10013524239/job/27681315505)

bors r- 

Please merge master and fix the issues. Thanks.

> bors r-
> 
> Please merge master and fix the issues. Thanks.

Sorry about that! I think we're now good to go.

Not your fault when the world shifts under you. Thanks.

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10016270737/job/27688988499)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10016270737/job/27688988589)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Some naive comments by someone who knows a bit of Lean/mathlib but nothing about matroids. My apologies for any stupid questions.

One more consideration: in other parts of mathlib we write out the full name `closure`. Here you have abbreviated to `cl`. I think that it would be good for uniformity to use `closure` everywhere.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
I'd rather write `M.E  M.cl X  M.E = M.cl X`.
I think that the current direction is better for rewriting using the RHS - it is far more like to `rw [h : M.cl X = M.E]` than the other way round.
OK, ignore my comment then. I was thinking about readability of the statement rather than its uses. Your point is more relevant.
Should this be a simp lemma?
Other definitions don't specify ` : Set ` in the set-builder notation. If I were writing it, I'd add the redundant type information everywhere as it is done here.

I tend to prefer things without the type annotation here - informally we are taking the intersection of the 'set of flats of M such that ...' so the type annotation is implicit in normal speech because of `M.Flat F`.
Alright! I was just checking it is intentional here.
I'd rather read `M.closure` than `M.cl`, but it is your call. Just FYI, almost no lines overflow with the longer identifier in this file.
I didn't take into account renaming constants containing `cl` in their name.
The notation is to line up with the normal pen-and-paper notation for closure.
Both lines can be replaced by `simp [h,  M.cl_iUnion_cl_eq_cl_iUnion]`.
This use of underscore feels pointless when it can be `mem_cl_of_mem' M rfl` literally.

`B` and `C` are not used. Neither are `I` and `J`.

From the last part, only `{e : }` is used.
Thanks! This is because the PR is just the beginning of the repo file, which requires more in its full version.
Local argument `{ : Type*}` is redundant as it is a variable for the whole file.
Arguments `Xs` and `Ys` could be implicit.
Yes, but I think that more often that not when applying the lemma one needs to specify them.
Why not `refine M.cl_subset_cl (iUnion_subset (fun i  (M.subset_cl _).trans ?_))` ?

```suggestion
@[mk_iff]
structure Flat (M : Matroid ) (F : Set ) : Prop where
  subset_of_basis_of_basis :  I X, M.Basis I F  M.Basis I X  X  F
  subset_ground : F  M.E
```

```suggestion
attribute [aesop unsafe 20% (rule_sets := [Matroid])] Flat.subset_ground
```

Thinking out loud for a bit...

If you choose to add `X \ M.E` to the closure, then it is still monotone and idempotent. You get `X  M.cl X` without assumptions, but now `M.cl X  M.E` will need an assumption.

On the other hand, it makes `M.cl` an example of a [ClosureOperator](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Closure.html#ClosureOperator). That would give you some API for free.

Naive question: is `M.cl X` an example of a flat? If so, I suspect that `M.cl` is part of a Galois correspondence (even Galois insertion) between flats and subsets. That would also give you a bunch of API for free.

Happy to hear your thoughts.

Thanks for this - I wasn't familiar with the `GaloisConnection` and `ClosureOperator` parts of mathlib, and gave this quite a lot of thought. 

Mathematically, you're absolutely on the money - if we have `M.E = univ`, then `M.closure` would give a `ClosureOperator` on `Set ` for which `Flat  IsClosed`, and we thus have a Galois insertion with the types `Set ` and `{F // M.Flat F}`. 

But because `IsClosed univ` is always true, we can't have all three of the following at once : 

(1) `M.E  univ`,
(2) every `Flat` is a subset of the ground set,
(3) `M.closure` is a `ClosureOperator` on `Set ` for which `Flat  IsClosed`

For instance, if we included `X \ M.E` in `M.cl X`, then we would get a `ClosureOperator`, but `IsClosed` would not correspond to `Matroid.Flat`, since (for example) the set `univ` would be closed but not a flat. Perhaps having this `ClosureOperator` would still be somewhat useful, but losing the property that `M.cl X  M.E` is not great for `aesop_mat`, and I think in practice would add a lot of extra assumptions to lemmas.  

I believe that (1) and (2) are important enough for the design of matroids that we have to give up (3). 

However, when it comes to piggybacking off the `ClosureOperator` and `GaloisInsertion` API, we can do something using subtypes. 
See `Matroid.subtypeClosure` as defined below. It allowed me to golf the proof of `closure_iUnion_closure_eq_closure_iUnion`,
and I think it'll be nice for making the `Flat` API simpler when we get there. 

That all said, after pushing, I will play around with including `X \ M.E` in `M.cl X` to see what it entails in terms of extra assumptions.

Thanks for writing down these reflections! Would you mind incorporating (parts of) this comment into the "Implementation notes" in the module docstring?

After that (and once CI passes), I think this PR is ready to be merged.
Great, thanks. At the moment I'm experimenting with the `X  M.cl X` design to see how much havoc it wreaks in my larger repo. If that turns out to be 'a lot', I'll go ahead with what you say.

One other option is to have both, where the current version would be consider "canonical" and the other is only there as implementation detail for setting up API. Because I do think that the other would give you a closure operator and a galois correspondence.
It could even be there only for illustrative purposes.
Is `M.cl  = ` true? If so, that seems like a good simp lemma?
No - for instance, if `M` is the matroid arising from a function `v :   V` for a vector space `V`, then `M.cl  = v ' {0}`.
Thanks! That is a helpful example.

```suggestion
since this would incorrectly force `univ` to always be a flat.) -/
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Data/Matroid/Closure): matroid closure
